data.title: âLongform on Apple Podcasts
data.meta_description: Interviews with writers, journalists, filmmakers, and podcasters about how they do their work. Hosted by Aaron Lammer, Max Linsky, and Evan Ratliff.
data.text:
This is the story of what happens when Evan Ratliff, co-host of Longform and a longtime tech journalist, makes a digital copy of himself, powered by AI, in order to understand how amazing and scary and utterly ridiculous the world is about to get.

In Episode 1, Evan clones his voice, hooks it up to ChatGPT and his phone line, and sends it off to tangle with customer service representatives.

New episodes drop on Tuesdays.

VisitÂ shellgame.coÂ to find out more, subscribe, and support the show.

Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

What would happen if you created a digital copy of yourself, powered by AI, and set it loose in the world? Over the past six months, Evan Ratliff has been trying to find out. He combined a clone of his voice, an AI chatbot, and a phone lineâmany phone lines, actuallyâinto what are called âvoice agents.â Then he sent them outâ¦ as himself. They talked to sources and colleagues (including his fellow Longform co-hosts), friends and family, scammers and spammers, other AI voice agents, and even therapists. The result is a story of what it feels like when you try to take control of the very technology that threatens to replace you.

New episodes drop on Tuesdays starting July 9.

VisitÂ shellgame.coÂ to find out more, subscribe, and support the show.

Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

John Jeremiah Sullivan is a contributing writer at theÂ New York Times MagazineÂ and has written forÂ Harper's,Â The New Yorker, andÂ GQ. He is the author ofÂ PulpheadÂ and the forthcomingÂ The Prime Minister of Paradise: The True Story of a Lost American History.

âI love making pieces of writing and trying to find the right language to say what I mean. It's such a wonderful way of being alive in the world. I mean, your material is all around you. ... I'm lucky that it has stayed interesting for me. It hasn't faded. The challenges of writing, they still glow.â

Ta-Nehisi Coates is an author and journalist. His next book isÂ The Message.

âI donât think we have the luxury as journalists of avoiding things because people might say bad things about us. I donât even think we have the luxury of avoiding things because we might get fired. I donât think we have the luxury of avoiding them because somebody might cancel some sort of public speech that we have. I then have to ask you, what are you in it for? Like, why did you come here? Did you come here just to make a living? Because there are many other things where you could make more money.â

Jay Caspian Kang is a staff writer forÂ The New YorkerÂ and a co-host ofÂ Time to Say Goodbye.

âAt some point, you have to kick it out the door, and itâs never finished to the degree that you would finish a magazine piece. But it, in some ways, is more interesting because it is produced in a short amount of time, and itâs read as something that is not supposed to be complete. Itâs just meant to provoke or to provide thought or whatever, to provide some sort of context on a certain issue or not. And I actually like that a lot better than the magazine writing. I respect the magazine writersâobviously, I was oneâbut for my disposition now, in my lifestyle, I actually enjoy having to produce this thing every week.â

Have a question for the mailbag?Â Email the showÂ or leave a voicemail at (929) 333-2908.
